slides.title: Why Ruby?
slides.content:
# Developer Happiness ğŸ˜Š

Optimized for humans, not machines.

Everything is an object, even numbers.

```ruby
5.times { print "Hello" }
```

slides.title: Ruby on Rails
slides.content:
# The Framework ğŸ›¤ï¸

A full-stack framework using **MVC** (Model-View-Controller).

Famous for "Convention over Configuration". It assumes what you want to do, saving you hours of setup.

slides.title: Gems
slides.content:
# Gems ğŸ’

Ruby libraries are called Gems.

Managed by `bundler`.

`Gemfile` lists dependencies (like `package.json` in Node).

```ruby
source 'https://rubygems.org'
gem 'rails', '~> 7.0'
```

slides.title: Active Record
slides.content:
# The Best ORM? ğŸ†

Active Record is the layer that connects objects to your database.

```ruby
# Use English!
user = User.find_by(name: "David")
user.posts.create(title: "New Post")
```
It reads like a sentence.

slides.quizQuestion: What is the core philosophy of Ruby on Rails?

slides.title: Blocks, Procs, Lambdas
slides.content:
# Closures ğŸ“¦

Ruby relies heavily on blocks (chunks of code passed to methods).

```ruby
[1, 2, 3].each do |n|
  puts n * 2
end
```
`do ... end` defines a block.

slides.title: Symbols
slides.content:
# Symbols :hello ğŸ†”

Immutable strings used as identifiers.

Faster and memory efficient compared to Strings.

```ruby
status = :active
user = { :name => "Sam" }
# or
user = { name: "Sam" }
```

slides.title: Modules & Mixins
slides.content:
# Traits ğŸ§¬

Ruby has single inheritance but supports Modules (Mixins).

You can include a module in multiple classes to share behavior.

```ruby
module Flyable
  def fly; puts "I can fly"; end
end

class Bird; include Flyable; end
```

slides.title: Scaffolding
slides.content:
# Rails Generate ğŸ—ï¸

Rails can generate entire features in seconds.

`rails generate scaffold Post title:string body:text`

Creates Model, View, Controller, Migration, and Routes instantly.

slides.title: Migrations
slides.content:
# Database Changes ğŸš§

Manage DB schema changes with code.

```ruby
class CreateUsers < ActiveRecord::Migration[7.0]
  def change
    create_table :users do |t|
      t.string :name
      t.string :email
      t.timestamps
    end
  end
end
```

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Ruby ğŸ“

Human-Centric.

- **Gems:** Library packaging.
- **Rails:** The framework.
- **Active Record:** The ORM.
- **Scaffold:** Code generation.
- **Symbols:** `:symbol` vs `"string"`.
